messages.message:
As Debby swirls just offshore, the heavy rain is expected to move north into parts of South Carolina and North Carolina that have already seen two billion-dollar floods in eight years.
South Carolina Governor Henry McMaster said Debby hasn’t yet been as bad as feared, but he warned residents the slow-moving storm was far from over.
It will be a nervous few days for northern South Carolina and southern North Carolina where forecasters warned up to 15 inches of rain could fall.
President Biden approved emergency declarations making federal disaster assistance available to Florida, Georgia, and South Carolina.
The hurricane center predicts the system could move up the middle of North Carolina, through Virginia and into the Washington, D.C., area by Saturday.

As Debby swirls just offshore, the heavy rain is expected to move north into parts of South Carolina and North Carolina that have already seen two billion-dollar floods in eight years.
South Carolina Governor Henry McMaster said Debby hasn't yet been as bad as feared, but he warned residents that the slow-moving storm was far from over.
North Carolina Governor Roy Cooper declared a state of emergency Monday, and Virginia Governor Glenn Youngkin declared the same for his state on Tuesday.
Green Pond in rural Colleton County, South Carolina, reported the most rain so far from Debby with just over 36 centimeters (14 inches).
President Joe Biden approved emergency declarations making federal disaster assistance available to Florida, Georgia and South Carolina.

CHARLESTON, S.C. (AP) — Tropical Storm Debby is taking a breather over the western Atlantic ocean but it isn’t done dousing the coastal Carolinas before it slowly marches north.
Debby was expected to turn north late Wednesday toward the South Carolina coastline for a second landfall, weather officials said Tuesday night.
The slow moving storm drenched coastal cities in Georgia and South Carolina late Monday into Tuesday, stirring up tornadoes and submerging streets with waist-high floodwaters.
As Debby swirls just offshore, the heavy rain is expected to move into parts of South and North Carolina that have already seen two billion-dollar floods in eight years.
Debby is finally forecast to pick up speed Thursday, and it could move up the middle of North Carolina, through Virginia and into the Washington area by Saturday.

Debby was expected to turn north late Wednesday toward the South Carolina coastline for a second landfall, weather officials said Tuesday night.
The slow moving storm drenched coastal cities in Georgia and South Carolina late Monday into Tuesday, stirring up tornadoes and submerging streets with waist-high floodwaters.
As Debby swirls just offshore, the heavy rain is expected to move into parts of South and North Carolina that have already seen two billion-dollar floods in eight years.
Debby is finally forecast to pick up speed Thursday, and it could move up the middle of North Carolina, through Virginia and into the Washington area by Saturday.

Debby was expected to turn north late Wednesday toward the South Carolina coastline for a second landfall, weather officials said Tuesday night.

As Debby swirls just offshore, the heavy rain is expected to move into parts of South and North Carolina that have already seen two billion-dollar floods in eight years.
North Carolina and Virginia have both declared a state of emergency.
Debby is finally forecast to pick up speed Thursday, and it could move up the middle of North Carolina, through Virginia and into the Washington area by Saturday.

Debby is finally forecast to pick up speed Thursday, and it could move up the middle of North Carolina, through Virginia and into the Washington area by Saturday.

Tropical Storm Debby swirls over Atlantic, expected to again douse the Carolinas before moving northCHARLESTON, South Carolina -- Tropical Storm Debby is taking a breather Wednesday over the western Atlantic Ocean but it isn't done dousing the coastal Carolinas before it slowly marches north.
Debby was expected to restrengthen and turn north toward the South Carolina coastline for a second landfall late Wednesday or early Thursday, weather officials said.
As Debby swirls just offshore, the heavy rain is expected to move into parts of South and North Carolina that have already seen two billion-dollar floods in eight years.
President Joe Biden approved emergency declarations making federal disaster assistance available to Florida, Georgia and South Carolina.
Debby is finally forecast to pick up speed Thursday, and it could move up the middle of North Carolina, through Virginia and into the Washington area by Saturday.

ATLANTA: Tropical Storm Debby inundated coastal Georgia and South Carolina with a deluge of rain on Tuesday (Aug 6) that could bring "catastrophic flooding" to Charleston, Savannah and other cities in the southeastern United States, the National Hurricane Center said.
At least six people have died in Florida and Georgia in the wake of the storm, which is expected to linger over the southeastern and mid-Atlantic coasts for days.
The storm featured 64kmh winds as it chugged along slowly at 8kmh to the northeast, with its centre located about 80km east of Savannah, Georgia, on Tuesday night.
More than 20cm of rain have already fallen on Savannah and Valdosta, Georgia, the National Weather Service said.
Charleston and Hilton Head, South Carolina, have received between 25cm and 30cm of rain so far, the weather service said, with more on the way.

Tropical Storm Debby inundated coastal Georgia and South Carolina with a deluge of rain yesterday that could bring "catastrophic flooding" to Charleston, Savannah and other cities in the south eastern United States, the National Hurricane Center has said.
"Debby is expected to produce potentially historic rainfall totals of 25cm and 51cm, with maximum amounts of 63.5cm, bringing areas of catastrophic flooding across portions of the eastern half of South Carolina, and southeast North Carolina through Friday," the NHC said.
Vehicles drive through a flooded street in Savannah, GeorgiaThe storm featured 64km/h winds as it chugged along slowly at 8km/h to the northeast, with its centre located about 80km east of Savannah, Georgia, last night.
Charleston and Hilton Head, South Carolina, have received between 25 and 30cm of rain so far, the weather service said, with more on the way.
In Savannah, rain was coming down hard outside the landmark Bellwether House, a 16-room bed-and-breakfast in the city's historic district, but general manager Victoria Hill was not too concerned.

ATLANTA, (Reuters) – Tropical Storm Debby inundated coastal Georgia and South Carolina with a deluge of rain that could bring “catastrophic flooding” to Charleston, Savannah and other cities on Tuesday, a day after it slammed into Florida’s Gulf Coast as a hurricane.
The storm featured 40-mile-per-hour (64 kph) winds as it moved slowly just south of Savannah, Georgia, on Tuesday afternoon.
More than 8 inches (20 cm) of rain have already fallen on Savannah and Valdosta, Georgia, the National Weather Service said.
A suspected twister flipped over cars and damaged restaurants in Moncks Corner, South Carolina, about 30 miles (48 km) north of Charleston, early on Tuesday morning.
The NHC said Debby would slow down and move east and off Georgia’s shore on Tuesday before turning north and drifting inland over South Carolina near Charleston on Thursday.

Tropical Storm Debby is taking a breather over the western Atlantic ocean but it isn’t done dousing the coastal Carolinas before it slowly marches north.
Debby was expected to turn north late Wednesday toward the South Carolina coastline for a second landfall, weather officials said Tuesday night.
The slow moving storm drenched coastal cities in Georgia and South Carolina late Monday into Tuesday, stirring up tornadoes and submerging streets with waist-high floodwaters.
As Debby swirls just offshore, the heavy rain is expected to move into parts of South and North Carolina that have already seen two billion-dollar floods in eight years.
Debby is finally forecast to pick up speed Thursday, and it could move up the middle of North Carolina, through Virginia and into the Washington area by Saturday.

CHARLESTON, S.C. -Tropical Storm Debby was swirling over coastal Georgia and Carolinas on Wednesday, its wide bands of rain swelling inland waterways before it slowly marches north.
Debby was expected to restrengthen a little and turn north toward the South Carolina coastline before its center makes a second landfall late Wednesday or early Thursday, weather officials said.
But its core was surrounded by drier air and the worst rainfall was falling hundreds of miles to the north, into eastern North Carolina before spreading into southeast Virginia.
The area of most concern Wednesday was in southeastern North Carolina, where Hurricane Matthew caused a historic billion-dollar flood in 2016.
Debby is finally forecast to pick up speed Thursday before weakening inland as the weather moves north over North Carolina and Virginia into the Washington area by Saturday.

Debby was expected to restrengthen and turn north toward the South Carolina coastline for a second landfall late Wednesday or early Thursday, weather officials.
The slow-moving storm drenched coastal cities in Georgia and South Carolina late Monday into Tuesday, stirring up tornadoes and submerging streets with waist-high floodwaters.
As Debby swirls just offshore, the heavy rain is expected to move into parts of South and North Carolina that have already seen two billion-dollar floods in eight years.

Debby is finally forecast to pick up speed Thursday, and it could move up the middle of North Carolina, through Virginia and into the Washington area by Saturday.

Debby was expected to turn north late Wednesday toward the South Carolina coastline for a second landfall, weather officials said Tuesday night.

MYRTLE BEACH, S.C. (WMBF) - Debby continues to drift around to our south, ushering in more rounds of flooding rain on tuesday.
FIRST ALERT: South Carolina is now under a State of Emergency from the impacts we will see from Debby.
(WMBF)LATEST ON DEBBYAt 5 am, the center of Tropical Storm Debby was located near latitude 31.9 North, longitude 79.5 West.
Tropical storm conditions are expected within the tropical storm warning area and possible within the tropical storm watch area in North Carolina beginning today and continuing through Thursday.
While not continuous, rain bands will usher in rounds of flooding rain through Thursday.

MYRTLE BEACH, S.C. (WMBF) - Tropical Storm Debby continues to drift around to our south, expected to make landfall in South Carolina early on Thursday.
A tornado watch is now in effect for Horry County through 11:00 PM (WMBF)TROPICAL STORM WARNING EXPANDED INLANDThe TROPICAL STORM WARNING has been expanded inland to include much of the Pee Dee.
Tropical storm force wind gusts of 50 mph are likely near the beaches with gusts of 4o to 45 mph likely inland.
The Tropical Storm Warning has been expanded inland to include Marion County, Interior Horry County and Florence County.
Tropical storm conditions are expected within the tropical storm warning area and possible within the tropical storm watch area in North Carolina today through Thursday.

messages.message:
Flash flooding traps drivers on NYC roads after storms dump 4 inches of rain on Big AppleFlash flooding left several drivers stranded in their cars in New York City on Tuesday.
Violent storms ripped through the Big Apple on Wednesday and dumped as much as four inches of rain in a matter of hours causing dangerous flash flooding that stranded drivers in their vehicles.
Tuesday’s rains dumped as much as four inches in parts of New York City.
The deluge was partially a result of Tropical Storm Debby, which made landfall as a Category 1 hurricane in Florida on Monday, killing at least five people, before it was downgraded to a tropical storm.
The tri-state area will likely see more showers beginning Wednesday afternoon before the leftovers of Tropical Storm Debbie whack the region from Thursday into the weekend, Tate said.

7 Tuesday’s rains dumped as much as four inches in parts of New York City.
The deluge was partially a result of Tropical Storm Debby, which made landfall as a Category 1 hurricane in Florida on Monday, killing at least five people, before it was downgraded to a tropical storm.
Getty Images7 Parts of the Bronx and Long Island saw more than 4 inches of rain.
At Newark Liberty International Airport in New Jersey, 134 flights were canceled and 149 flights delayed.
The tri-state area will likely see more showers beginning Wednesday afternoon before the leftovers of Tropical Storm Debby whack the region from Thursday into the weekend, Tate said.

Forecasters said the storms were enhanced by moisture drifting up from Tropical Storm Debby.
Officials said its goal of keeping unnecessary people out during the worst of the rains from Tropical Storm Debby worked.
Henry McMaster said Tuesday that Tropical Storm Debby hasn’t been as bad as feared.
Debby brings flooding, tornadoes to South CarolinaSouth Carolina is bracing for days of rain through Thursday from Tropical Storm Debby.
“We are facing an unprecedented weather event with Hurricane Debby,” said Jodie Fiske, Manatee County's public safety director.

CHARLOTTE, N.C. (WBTV) - Tropical Storm Debby will bring rain and the likelihood of flash flooding to a large part of North Carolina, with Charlotte impacts peaking on Thursday.
Our First Alert Weather team predicts three to six inches of rain along the Interstate 77 corridor, with the greatest impacts unfolding south and east of Charlotte.
Debby will likely bring several inches of rain to the Charlotte region.
A First Alert Weather Day is in place for Thursday when Debby’s forecast is expected to move over our viewing area.
>> Related: Tropical Storm Debby producing gusty winds, tornado chances across the CarolinasA State of Emergency was activated in North Carolina Monday afternoon in anticipation of severe weather brought on by Debby.

SALISBURY, N.C. (WBTV) - Rowan-Salisbury Schools canceled the first day of class -- which was set for Thursday -- amid Tropical Storm Debby.
Flood watches are in place; click here for the latest weather alerts.
A First Alert Weather Day is in place for Thursday when Debby’s forecast is expected to move over our viewing area.
>> Related: Here’s how much rain to expect in Charlotte this week from Tropical Storm DebbyA State of Emergency was activated in North Carolina Monday afternoon in anticipation of severe weather brought on by Debby.
The emergency declaration was made the day before potentially historic rainfall and subsequent flooding was expected to reach the Carolinas.

messages.message:
Storm Debby is slowly swirling over South Carolina, spawning damaging tornadoes and dumping catastrophic rainfall across low-lying coastal regions.
Another area of concern on Wednesday was southeastern North Carolina, where Hurricane Matthew caused a historic billion-dollar flood in 2016.
Charleston, South Carolina, officials lifted a curfew Wednesday following heavy rains that caused flooding and closed dozens of roads Monday and Tuesday.
The lunch crowd was pouring into the Brown Dog Deli in downtown Charleston after two days of preparing for and hunkering down in Tropical Storm Debby.
The tropical storm could make a second landfall in either North Carolina or South Carolina, expected late Wednesday or early Thursday.

A woman walks through winds from Tropical Storm Debby on August 7, 2024 in Garden City Beach, South Carolina.
Crews work on a storm drain due to rain and storm surge caused by Tropical Storm Debby on August 06, 2024 in Savannah, Georgia.
In this aerial view, A street is flooded by Tropical Storm Debby on August 6, 2024, in Ridgeland, South Carolina.
The lunch crowd was pouring into the Brown Dog Deli in downtown Charleston after two days of preparing for and hunkering down in Tropical Storm Debby.
The tropical storm could make a second landfall in either North Carolina or South Carolina, expected late Wednesday or early Thursday.

CHARLESTON, S.C. — Tropical Storm Debby pushed bad weather up the East Coast on Wednesday, colliding with other systems and bringing no respite to residents as far away as the Great Lakes and New Jersey, where heavy rain flooded highways and streets and stranded motorists.
An additional 4 to 8 inches of rain could fall, said John Quagliariello, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service in Columbia.
Another area of concern on Wednesday was southeastern North Carolina, where Hurricane Matthew caused a historic billion-dollar flood in 2016.
The tropical storm could make a second landfall in either North Carolina or South Carolina, expected late Wednesday or early Thursday.
The lunch crowd was pouring into the Brown Dog Deli in downtown Charleston after two days of preparing for and hunkering down in Tropical Storm Debby.

“If the dam breaks, flash flooding will occur immediately downstream of the dam,” the weather service said.
Another area of concern on Wednesday was southeastern North Carolina, where Hurricane Matthew caused a historic billion-dollar flood in 2016.
A state of emergency was in effect for both North Carolina and Virginia.
The tropical storm could make a second landfall in either North Carolina or South Carolina, expected late Wednesday or early Thursday.
The lunch crowd was pouring into the Brown Dog Deli in downtown Charleston after two days of preparing for and hunkering down in Tropical Storm Debby.

Tropical Storm Debby swirls over Atlantic, still dumping rain on the Carolinas before moving northStephen B. Morton / APCHARLESTON, S.C. — Tropical Storm Debby was swirling over coastal Georgia and Carolinas on Wednesday, its wide bands of rain swelling inland waterways before it slowly marches north.
But its core was surrounded by drier air and the worst rainfall was falling hundreds of miles to the north, into eastern North Carolina before spreading into southeast Virginia.
